description: Set it up by transferring all relevant info from my spreadsheet, and configuring it to my needs. It is working well. I now download income, expenses and tax data to further process in my spreadsheet as a back end. For instance, projections, budget planning, investment decisions. The one thing that is not working is Yahoo JSON to obtain securities quotes, but not the fault of GnuCash, but Yahoo blocking it. I can, however, export those from my spreadsheet and have GC import them. And presto, I have a fully functional and effective personal accounting system. Thanks!

I started off with some calc sheets with libreoffice. Then I looked at mobile apps like 'you need a budget'. All of these are easier to learn but then I heard so much good about this. So I tried it out. Didn't understand at first. Then I read the documentation and followed the guide. The main reason I found it hard to understand at first is that it is a double entry accounting system. This is actually the biggest strength yet turned out to be the single most important thing to understand. Like the documentation says under 'Accounting Concepts'. Try to make sure you understand that before going on. If you still don't understand and find yourself lost in the application. Go back to that. You most likely didn't get it even though you thought you did.

Once you get it this tool is absolutely amazing. The details. Incredible. The year-end reports. Amazing. Sure could they be more modern and flashy. Absolutely, but don't just wish. Make it so. Gnu cash has all the data. Make a plugin or contribute with those flashy year-end summaries and statistics generators. Think of this as your giant transaction database. As long as you fill it in you can do all kinds of amazing things in the future. You can also have your stocks listed in here with the perl plugin. I use Yahoo to get and update exchange rates automatically. That works great but that really does need quite a lot of manual work to function. It at least wasn't that plug and play for me. 

GnuCash also has a mobile app in case you need such a thing.

I don’t think it’s easy to make accounting intuitive, but GnuCash has managed to make a fairly intuitive interface with a moderately shallow learning curve. It’s reliable (I’ve been using it without problems or data loss for a decade) and contains most of the features I need.

I worry that with the rise of online-only banks with new ways of sending customers their statements, that GnuCash might get left behind. Hopefully the GnuCash developers will keep on top of that.

2020-06-20 - An excellent accounting software. However after installation on newly installed Ubuntu 20.04 (from Flatpak source), it does not start. The best it did (only once) was to bring up the startup logo and tips dialogue box, however they were unresponsive and close.
I can understand that some folks will find this software initially difficult to use. However, with a little perseverance and a noticeable amount of time you will grow to realise its potential.
summary: Very good, but it does take time to learn to use

description: Previously had to install from repos because the flatpak version was awful - extremely slow start times and crashed. This all seems to be fixed now - it runs great and starts up instantly. Big thanks to the developers.
I got that gnu cash I don't actually use this program I just like the name gnu cash lololololooln
Maybe a bit difficult to start with, but it works really well.
summary: I use it for my bookkeeping

description: I got that gnu cash I don't actually use this program I just like the name gnu cash lololololooln

Saw the early childhood rating and thought this would be the final solution that I am looking for to help my toddler finally grasp the fundamentals of accounting. I'm seriously disgustingly disappointed in his performance and lack of will to better himself, but the program is actually well made and in depth.
I use it for my home and business account management
I hope after this review, the installation begins! If so I will come back and update
Tested with Mobian. Doesn't scale to the PinePhone screen size unfortunately.
There is no posibility to disable autocomplete, this is a buggy and annoying function and makes the software unusable for me
It's free double entry accounting software that works really well and offers lots of features. Not the best, but you can't ask for more for that price.

I was using Banktivity on my Mac, but they became a subscription service. With a few hours, GNUCash is much more especially if you understand accounting principles. I now work on my finances on ANY operating system, and I have also started donating yearly to the GNUCash project. Great!
I can keep a simple record of my finances.
The app has been finally updated to a newer version, no need to git clone it now anymore!
summary: Great app, the app has been updated to 4.7 now!

description:
Been using this for a few years now. It's ability to track all your expenses, spit out reports, and connect to your bank with the online connection is amazing. The only weak spot would be the budgeting which is still quite minimal/weak. 

I like it so much I've donated and set a reminder to donate each year for its continued development.
summary: The best money manager for Linux

description: easy to use and comes with enough of the advanced features
It took me some time to learn how to use this. Also because I'm not an accounting expert. I use this for accounting of my one person business.
summary: Powerful enough for a small business

description: GnuCash helps and I've been using it for years because I couldn'f find a better option, but it doesn't compute the cash flow correctly when there are transactions between more than 2 accounts, doesn't compute automatically depreciation (you have to do most things manually inside GnuCash), doesn't accept as input some ISO standard ways to write numbers (for instance space as thousand separator), doesn't handle several users' rights (as your accountant and your cashier), doesn't output spreadsheet files etc..
summary: Helps but is very US American, and has serious flaws

description:
I'v previously been using the trial version of moneydance and i'd say that app is better for begginers. When the trial ended, i tried gnucash, imported my finances from moneydance (yes, there are issues). This is actually a powerful tool if you know how to use it. So here's the breakdown:

1. Interface is just OK, not good by any means. It looks like your standard accounting on a spreadsheet software. 

2. Functionality is there but some features like statistics and graph are hard to use, for me atleast.

3. Crossplatform support is a bonus since i have windows and mac laptops and i can sync .gnucash files with dropbox.

I would give it a five star if the interface was better.

I don't do any Flatpak or etc!

Pure RPM well tested, safe and secure is prefered - ALWAYS!

It really helps me to manage my personal finance. It's very easy to use and although I am still learning the report generation functionality at first sight I can see there a lot more functionality that can play in my favor.

GnuCash works, but is very US-centered and several annoying mistakes are never corrected. GnuCash doesn't calculate cash flow correctly in case of multi-account transactions because one of the developpers' friend said to him something contrary to the IFRS (and to the very notion of cash flow). It's impossible to copy and cut a number in ISO format into GnuCash (with a space as thousand separator). If you're in an environnement were a dot is used as decimal separator but you've recorded scheduled transactions with a comma, then your decimals are just ignored. etc..
summary: Works but mistakes hasn't been corrected for years

description: Gnucash is a great tool for small businesses but it does take time to learn the complex transactions properly.  There are also still aspects of it that need improving and a few that do not work for everyone. However in all I thoroughly recommended it, especially if you only need to record basic transactions.
summary: Worth learning how to use it

description: Leider startete die Anwendung nach der Installation nicht. Auch ein Neustart brachte keine Besserung.
summary: Läuft nicht unter Fedora 32 X Window

description: Läuft soweit gut auf Ubuntu 20.10
Keeps track of all my money-related stuff. Need to learn a lot at the start, but then it works better than anything else.
Me parece una aplicación excelente, la use durante un tiempo pero tiendo a ser un poco dejado.
отличное приложения для личных финансов
Просто и эффективно. Пользуюсь.
